Description:
In the wake of the catastrophic Franco-Prussian War of 1870-71, the artist painted this picture of a young woman seated in a devastated landscape holding an oak twig as a symbol of hope for the nation's recovery from war and deprivation. This painting was exhibited at the Paris Salon of 1872. A smaller variant, showing the subject nude, is at the Musée d'Orsay, Paris.

Puvis de Chavannes was one of the most original artists of his generation. His utopian visions, in which the figures seem to float in a dream-like landscape, served as a point of departure for many younger artists, such as Paul Gauguin (1848-1903) and Henri Matisse (1869-1954).
Dimensions: H: 40 3/8 x W: 51 in. (102.5 x 129.5 cm); Framed H: 53 1/4 x W: 63 1/2 x D: 5 1/4 in. (135.3 x 161.3 x 13.3 cm); Framed H in travel frame without build-up: 51 1/4 x W: 61 7/8 x D: 2 in. (130.18 x 157.16 x 5.08 cm)

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Triumph of French Painting: Masterpieces from Ingres to Matisse
Exhibitions.Textblock: Triumph of French Painting: Masterpieces from Ingres to Matisse. Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore; Philbrook Museum of Art, Tulsa; Norton Museum of Art, West Palm Beach; Dayton Art Institute, Dayton; Royal Academy of Arts, London; Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo. 2000-2002.

Exhibitions.Textblock: 19th Century Masterpieces from the Walters Art Museum. Santa Barbara Museum of Art, Santa Barbara; Jack S. Blanton Museum of Art, Austin. 2010-2011.

Exhibitions.Textblock: A Magnificent Age: Masterpieces from the Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City; Mint Museum of Art, Charlotte. 2002-2004.

Exhibitions.Textblock: Manet, Monet, and the Gare Saint-Lazare. National Gallery of Art, Washington. 1998.

Inscriptions: [Date] Lower left: 1872; [Signature] Lower left: P. Purvis de Chavannes
Provenance: Durand-Ruel, Paris, prior to 1872 Salon, by purchase [from the artist]; Patou, Paris [date of acquisition unknown], by purchase; Durand-Ruel [date of acquisition unknown], by purchase; Erwin Davis, New York, 1890, by purchase; E. F. Miliken Sale, New York, February 14, 1902, no. 25; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1902, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Hope
